papers.title: Establishing Workload Identity for Zero Trust CI/CD: From Secrets to SPIFFE-Based Authentication
papers.abstract: The paper examines how CI/CD systems can shift from static credentials to more secure identity models. It introduces SPIFFE as a runtime-issued identity framework for non-human actors, demonstrating how this approach decouples identity from infrastructure and enables stronger authentication across job runners and workloads. The work explores policy alignment, workload attestation, and mutual authentication while advocating for Zero Trust architecture in CI/CD environments.

papers.title: A Novel Zero-Trust Identity Framework for Agentic AI: Decentralized Authentication and Fine-Grained Access Control
papers.abstract: The paper argues that conventional identity management systems are inadequate for multi-agent AI systems. It proposes a framework using rich, verifiable Agent Identities based on decentralized identifiers and verifiable credentials. The approach incorporates an Agent Naming Service, dynamic access controls, and zero-knowledge proofs for privacy-preserving verification across heterogeneous agent communication systems.

papers.title: AI Agents with Decentralized Identifiers and Verifiable Credentials
papers.abstract: The paper addresses a key limitation in LLM-based AI agents—their inability to establish differentiated trust when beginning agent-to-agent interactions. The authors propose equipping agents with self-sovereign digital identities using W3C Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) combined with W3C Verifiable Credentials (VCs). This framework enables agents to prove ownership of their self-controlled DIDs for authentication purposes and to establish various cross-domain trust relationships. The work includes a prototypical implementation demonstrating technical feasibility alongside identified limitations when LLMs control security procedures alone.

papers.title: Authenticated Delegation and Authorized AI Agents
papers.abstract: The paper introduces a framework for secure delegation of authority to AI agents, addressing challenges around authorization and accountability. It extends OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect protocols with agent-specific credentials and metadata while maintaining compatibility with existing authentication infrastructure. The authors also propose mechanisms for converting natural language permissions into auditable access control settings, enabling appropriate scoping of AI agent capabilities.

papers.title: Identity Management for Agentic AI: The new frontier of authorization, authentication, and security for an AI agent world
papers.abstract: This OpenID Foundation whitepaper addresses urgent challenges in authentication, authorization, and identity management emerging from rapid AI agent deployment. It examines existing protocols and best practices while proposing a strategic roadmap for handling access control, agent-centric identities, and delegated authority in future autonomous systems.

papers.title: Infrastructure for AI Agents
papers.abstract: The paper proposes agent infrastructure—external technical systems and protocols designed to manage interactions between AI agents and their environments. The authors identify three key functions: attributing actions to specific agents or actors, shaping agent interactions, and detecting/remedying harmful agent actions. They argue this infrastructure is essential for ecosystems of autonomous agents, much like how the Internet relies on foundational protocols.

papers.title: KubeIntellect: A Modular LLM-Orchestrated Agent Framework for End-to-End Kubernetes Management
papers.abstract: KubeIntellect is an LLM-powered system designed to simplify Kubernetes administration. The framework enables natural language interaction across the full range of Kubernetes operations—including reads, writes, deletions, access controls, and lifecycle management. It features modular agents organized by function (logs, metrics, RBAC) and orchestrated by a supervisor component. The system incorporates memory checkpoints, human clarification options, and dynamic task sequencing. According to the paper, evaluation demonstrated a 93% tool synthesis success rate and 100% reliability across 200 natural language queries, showcasing its effectiveness in managing diverse infrastructure workloads.

papers.title: KubeGuard: LLM-Assisted Kubernetes Hardening via Configuration Files and Runtime Logs Analysis
papers.abstract: The paper introduces KubeGuard, a framework that uses large language models to enhance Kubernetes security. It addresses overly permissive configurations by analyzing runtime logs and manifests to generate hardened resource configurations with least-privilege principles, supporting Roles, NetworkPolicies, and Deployments.

papers.title: Agentic AI Security: Threats, Defenses, Evaluation, and Open Challenges
papers.abstract: The paper examines security risks in AI agents powered by large language models that can plan, use tools, access memory, and operate autonomously. It presents a taxonomy of threats specific to agentic AI, reviews recent benchmarks and evaluation methodologies, and discusses defense strategies from both technical and governance perspectives.

papers.title: Streamlining Resilient Kubernetes Autoscaling with Multi-Agent Systems via an Automated Online Design Framework
papers.abstract: The paper addresses operational resilience challenges in Kubernetes clusters by proposing a multi-agent system approach to autoscaling. Rather than optimizing single metrics, the researchers decompose resilience goals into failure-specific sub-goals delegated to collaborative agents. Their framework involves four phases: creating a digital twin from cluster data, training agents in simulation, analyzing agent behavior for transparency, and deploying policies to production. Results show their approach outperforms existing methods under adversarial conditions like DDoS attacks.

key_findings.spiffe_svid_research: Paper #1 (Avirneni 2025) provides the most comprehensive treatment of SPIFFE/SVID for workload identity in CI/CD, demonstrating runtime attestation mechanisms for ephemeral jobs without hardcoded trust or pre-registered secrets.
key_findings.agentic_ai_identity: Papers #2, #3, #4, and #5 form a comprehensive foundation for AI agent identity management, covering zero-trust frameworks, decentralized identifiers (DIDs), verifiable credentials (VCs), and OAuth 2.0/OpenID Connect extensions for agent delegation.
key_findings.kubernetes_workloads: Papers #7, #8, and #10 address container orchestration challenges, with #8 (KubeGuard) providing LLM-assisted runtime analysis for least-privilege configurations, directly relevant to ephemeral workload security.
key_findings.infrastructure_protocols: Paper #6 presents foundational thinking on agent infrastructure protocols, identifying action attribution and identity as critical functions for autonomous agent ecosystems.
key_findings.security_framework: Paper #9 provides comprehensive threat taxonomy and defense strategies specific to agentic AI systems, essential for understanding security implications of ephemeral agent identities.

notes: All 10 papers are from 2025, representing cutting-edge research in ephemeral workload identity, AI agent authentication, and container orchestration security. The collection heavily features MIT and OpenID Foundation contributions, with strong representation from industry-academic collaborations. SPIFFE/SVID coverage is limited to 1 primary paper, but complemented by broader identity frameworks applicable to workload scenarios.
